week1_questions.question: In the context of SDLC, which of the following would most likely be the consequence of skipping the 'Analysis' phase?
options: Better time management and early delivery
More flexibility in the design phase
Unclear system requirements and user dissatisfaction

week1_questions.question: Why is it critical to distinguish between 'systems development methodologies' and 'software development methodologies'?
options: They are two names for the same concept
System development focuses on hardware integration, while software development focuses on code
System methodologies emphasize broader organizational impacts and frameworks
Software methodologies are agile-based only, while systems are more waterfall-focused

week1_questions.question: In a situation where user feedback is unpredictable and subject to frequent changes, which SDLC methodology would be the least effective?
Which of the following SDLC phases is most likely to encounter significant rework if requirements were not correctly captured during the 'Analysis' phase?
Which statement best captures the weakness of the Waterfall model in modern iterative development environments?
options: It allows only a single pass through the phases, preventing necessary iterations
It is too focused on system performance
It encourages continuous changes to requirements
It leads to faster project completion than Agile

week1_questions.question: Considering an Agile environment, why would Scrum's short iterations be particularly useful for high-risk projects?
options: It emphasizes frequent deployment of incomplete systems
It reduces the financial risk by shortening feedback loops and catching issues early
It focuses on detailed documentation and phase completion
It allows skipping testing phases when necessary

week1_questions.question: If the objective of a project is to provide an initial working prototype to stakeholders as quickly as possible, which SDLC model would be the most effective and why?
options: Waterfall, because of its emphasis on requirement stability
Prototyping, because it focuses on early user involvement and refining requirements
Agile, because of its flexibility to revisit each phase
Parallel Development, because of concurrent workstreams

week1_questions.question: Which aspect of Prototyping development is most critical in refining unclear user requirements?
options: Prototyping sessions with limited stakeholder involvement
User testing of preliminary system models
Strict adherence to predefined system architecture

week1_questions.question: What is the most significant risk associated with failing to re-evaluate earlier phases in Waterfall-based projects?
options: System architecture will be more modular than expected
Significant design or requirement flaws may only be identified during later stages

week1_questions.question: Which phase of the SDLC has the highest potential for long-term cost savings if performed thoroughly and accurately?
What distinguishes 'Phased Development' from other methodologies, particularly in relation to its delivery schedule?
options: It requires all features to be developed upfront
It releases the system in multiple versions, each adding functionality incrementally
It focuses entirely on customer feedback before building anything
It never proceeds past the prototype phase

week1_questions.question: In the context of Agile methodology, which activity is most likely to occur within a single iteration?
options: Development, testing, and evaluation of a feature set

week1_questions.question: Which SDLC model is most suitable for a project with unclear requirements that may evolve over time?
What is the primary benefit of using the Agile model over the Waterfall model?
options: Agile ensures faster deployment of systems
Agile allows continuous user feedback and iterative development
Agile is less expensive to implement than Waterfall
Agile requires less documentation than Waterfall

week1_questions.question: Which type of diagram is most commonly used to model the relationships between system components in the design phase?
In the SDLC, what is the primary focus of the 'Design' phase?
options: Defining the architecture and components of the system

week1_questions.question: What is the major disadvantage of the Waterfall model?
options: It is too rigid and does not easily allow changes once a phase is completed
It is too focused on testing
It focuses too much on documentation
It has no clear requirements phase

week1_questions.question: In the Agile model, what is a 'sprint'?
options: A short, time-boxed period to complete a set amount of work
A phase where the system undergoes extensive testing

week1_questions.question: Which phase in the SDLC is responsible for fixing issues discovered during user acceptance testing?
What is the primary focus during the 'Maintenance' phase of the SDLC?
options: Adding new features to the system
Ensuring the system continues to operate effectively by fixing bugs and making improvements

week1_questions.question: What distinguishes the Spiral model from the Waterfall model in the SDLC?
options: The Spiral model focuses on risk analysis and iterative cycles
The Spiral model is cheaper than Waterfall
The Spiral model eliminates the need for a design phase
The Spiral model is linear like Waterfall

week1_questions.question: In a traditional SDLC approach, which phase typically involves creating system specifications based on requirements?
Which of the following best describes the key goal of the 'Planning' phase in SDLC?
options: Defining the scope and objectives of the project

week1_questions.question: What is a key benefit of using the Spiral model over the Waterfall model?
options: It allows for continuous user feedback and better risk management
It eliminates the need for a testing phase
It focuses on quicker delivery without iterations

week1_questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'Feasibility Study' during the Planning phase?
options: To determine if the project is technically and financially viable

week1_questions.question: Which of the following is a major disadvantage of the Spiral model?
options: It is costly due to its emphasis on risk analysis and iterations
It does not allow for feedback from users
It does not support complex system development

week1_questions.question: What is the primary focus during the 'Implementation' phase of the SDLC?
options: Developing system code based on design specifications

week1_questions.question: Which of the following SDLC models best supports projects with rapidly changing requirements?
What is the main goal of 'User Acceptance Testing' (UAT) in the SDLC?
options: To verify that the system meets user requirements before deployment
To ensure the system is free from bugs
To gather user feedback during system development

week1_questions.question: Which SDLC model is best suited for small, low-risk projects with stable requirements?
Which SDLC phase focuses on identifying and fixing errors before system deployment?
In Agile, what is the primary purpose of daily stand-up meetings?
options: To discuss project costs and finances
To synchronize the team and address blockers quickly

week1_questions.question: What is the key characteristic of the 'V-Model' in SDLC?
options: It emphasizes testing at every phase of development
It allows for feedback loops and user interaction
It eliminates the need for documentation
It is focused on high-level architectural design

week1_questions.question: Which of the following is the main objective of the 'Requirements Gathering' phase?
options: To identify the needs and expectations of system users

week1_questions.question: What is the primary risk associated with skipping the 'Testing' phase in the SDLC?
options: The system will not meet user requirements
The project will go over budget
The system may contain undetected errors
There will be delays in project planning

week1_questions.question: What is the focus of 'System Design' in SDLC?
options: Creating system architecture and data models

week1_questions.question: What is the main advantage of using the Prototyping model?
options: It ensures the system is developed faster than Agile
It allows for early user feedback and requirement refinement
It eliminates the need for a Testing phase

week1_questions.question: Which of the following best describes the 'Maintenance' phase in the SDLC?
options: Monitoring system performance and making necessary updates or fixes
Writing code for new system features

week1_questions.question: In which SDLC phase would 'Feasibility Study' typically occur?
Why is the Agile model more suitable for projects with uncertain or evolving requirements?
options: It focuses on creating extensive documentation
It allows for continuous iterations and quick adjustments to feedback
It eliminates the need for testing phases
It ensures faster delivery without iterations

week1_questions.question: Which SDLC model focuses heavily on risk management and iterative development?
What is the main difference between 'Prototyping' and 'Waterfall' in the SDLC?
options: Prototyping allows for early user feedback, while Waterfall is linear
Waterfall focuses on small, iterative releases
